Award.AwardTitle: Ambient Near-Coastal Seismic Noise and Temporal Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration: The researchers will use the locations of secondary ocean microseisms noise to improve the<br/>temporal resolution of changes in crustal velocity, and to map the locations of coastal<br/>reflections of primary ocean waves. The proposed microseisms source location technique<br/>is based on an algorithm developed for real-time earthquake locations and is suitable for<br/>areas like Southern California where multiple simultaneous sources are located within a<br/>few hundred km offshore and where there is a well distributed seismic array on land. The<br/>use of source locations overcomes a problem with standard correlation methods that<br/>require a random distribution of sources to achieve precise measurements, which<br/>translates to long correlation times and hence a reduced temporal resolution. Using a set<br/>of source locations, a shorter synthetic seismogram can be used in the correlation. The<br/>coastal reflection points will be determined by forming an adjoint problem with the<br/>hypothesized reflection source and an incident primary wavefield determined from high resolution<br/>Wave Action Models (WAM's).<br/><br/>The source locations procedure is demonstrated with both a synthetic and real data<br/>examples. The results show that there are often many source points active at any given<br/>time. They provide two independent approaches: (1)<br/>Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) measurements of the intensity of wave-wave<br/>interactions at the source regions ? a necessary condition for microseisms generation. A<br/>new airborne system that will be flown in June 2008 over the offshore S. California to<br/>look for opposing ocean wavefields which are indicative of the source points. (2) A<br/>comparison between the amplitudes of the observed micoseisms and estimated<br/>amplitudes calculated using the source locations and the theory of ocean microseisms.<br/><br/>The nature of the<br/>coastal reflections is currently poorly understood. This research will provide the<br/>opportunity to develop a model for this process and to ultimately to generate a description<br/>of the complete wave-field that can be incorporated into the next generation of Wave<br/>Action Models. Microseisms provide a means to continuously monitor the Rayleigh<br/>wave speed across the Los Angeles basins as a potential proxy for stress changes. The<br/>use of sources in this procedure increases the temporal resolutions and removes the<br/>problem of systematic bias due to the assumption of random source locations.<br/><br/>This research bridges three communities: radar interferometry,<br/>oceanography and seismology and hence has the potential to spur research in all these<br/>areas. Determining the mechanisms for coastal reflections will significantly enhance the<br/>community wave action models. The application to southern California can be extended<br/>to several other areas including northern California, Cascadia, and Japan. The procedure<br/>established by this research could become part of the standard seismic monitoring of<br/>Southern California
